facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February of the former Bombay High Court in Appeal of 1957 from original decree.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February of the former Bombay High Court in Appeal of 1957 from original decree.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered on February 17, 1964 by MUDHOLKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: February 17, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by - MUDHOLKAR, J.-The question which arises for companysideration in this appeal

facts.text: Will alleged to have been executed by Ramdhan on May 23, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for companysideration in this appeal by a certificate granted by the High Court of Bombay is whether a will alleged to have been executed by one Ramdhan on May 23, 1947

facts.text: Ramdhan bequeathed almost his entire property to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: is genuine or is a fabrication. By this will, Ramdhan is alleged to have bequeathed almost his entire property companysisting of 16 fields assessed to land revenue at Rs. 425/- per annum, five houses, a shop and movables companysisting of 800 tolas of gold, 1,000 tolas of silver, Rs. 50,0001/- cash and Rs. 15,000/-- due from debtors as well as cattle, agricultural implements, utensils, etc., to the appellant,

facts.text: Property consists of 16 fields assessed to land revenue at Rs. 425/- per annum, five houses, a shop and movables consisting of 800 tolas of gold, 1,000 tolas of silver, Rs. 50,000/- cash and Rs. 15,000/- due from debtors as well as cattle, agricultural implements, utensils, etc.

anchor.surface_text: By this will, Ramdhan is alleged to have bequeathed almost his entire property companysisting of 16 fields assessed to land revenue at Rs. 425/- per annum, five houses, a shop and movables companysisting of 800 tolas of gold, 1,000 tolas of silver, Rs. 50,0001/- cash and Rs. 15,000/-- due from debtors as well as cattle, agricultural implements, utensils, etc.,

facts.text: Appellant is the grandson of one of the three predeceased uncles of Ramdhan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the grandson of one of the three predeceased uncles of Ramdhan, and the ground on which the widow and the daughters were practically excluded by Ramdhan

facts.text: Ramdhan practically excluded his widow Sitabai and his three married daughters.

anchor.surface_text: and the ground on which the widow and the daughters were practically excluded by Ramdhan is said to be the strained relations which developed between Ramdhan and his wife during his last days.

facts.text: Sitabai entitled to receive only a maintenance of Rs. 40/- per month under the will.

anchor.surface_text: and that she was entitled to receive only a maintenance of Rs. 40/- per month under the will of Ramdhan.

facts.text: Ramdhan died on October 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Ramdhan died on October 31. 1948, and Sitabai, who was all along living with him, came into possession of Ramdhans property.

facts.text: Sitabai came into possession of Ramdhan's property after his death.

anchor.surface_text: Ramdhan died on October 31. 1948, and Sitabai, who was all along living with him, came into possession of Ramdhans property.

facts.text: Appellant did not try to disturb Sitabai's possession.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the appellant did number try to disturb her possession. According to him, he allowed Sitabai to remain in possession on his behalf,

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit in District Court at Parbhani.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these allegations, the plaintiff instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises, in the District Court at Parbhani.

facts.text: Sitabai denied execution of the will and relationship claimed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Sitabai denied the execution of the alleged will by Ramdhan, and also denied the relationship claimed by the appellant with Ramdhan.

facts.text: Sitabai in exclusive possession after Ramdhan's death.

anchor.surface_text: According to her, after Ramdhans death she was in exclusive possession of the property, that she is a helpless widow without a male issue,

facts.text: Madanlal joined as party claiming to be adopted son of Ramdhan in Chait Samvat 1999 according to custom in State of Udaipur.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the suit, one Madanlal was joined as a party to it on the. basis of his claim to be the adopted son of Ramdhan. lie also challenged the genuineness of the will. According to him, he was adopted by Ramdhan in the month of Chait, Samvat, 1999 according to the prevailing custom in the State of Udaipur.

facts.text: Sitabai died during pendency of suit; daughters Champabai, Rambhabai, Rajubai and son-in-law Ram Pershad brought on record.

anchor.surface_text: Sitabai died during the pendency of the suit, and her daughters, Champabai, Rambhabai, and Rajubai as also Ram Pershad, one of Sitabais sons-in-law, who was alleged to have obtained possession of the property after the death of Sitabai, were brought on record as the legal representatives of Sitabai.

facts.text: Trial Court held in favour of appellant: related to Ramdhan, will genuine, negatived Madanlal's adoption claim, decreed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held in favour of the appellant that he was related to Ramdhan, as alleged by him, and that the will executed by Ramdhan was genuine. It also negatived Madanlals claim of having been adopted by Ramdhan. On these findings, that Court decreed the appellants suit.

facts.text: High Court held will not genuine, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The. legal representatives of Sitabai thereupon preferred an appeal before the High Court, which held that the will set up by the appellant is number genuine, and on that ground, dismissed his suit.

facts.text: Appellant examined himself, scribe Venkat Rajaram, attesting witnesses Raja Kaniahprasad, Rasheeduddin Ahmed, Wamanlal.

anchor.surface_text: In support of the will, the appellant examined himself, the scribe, Venkat Rajaram and three of the attesting witnesses, Raja Kaniahprasad, Rasheeduddin Ahmed and Wamanlal.

facts.text: Respondents led evidence that Ramdhan could not have been at Hyderabad on May 23, 1947 as he was at a village nearly 300 miles distant till afternoon previous day.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the respondents have led evidence to show that Ramdhan companyld number have been at Hyderabad where the will is alleged to have been executed, on May 23, 1947, because till the afternoon of the previous day he was at a village nearly 300 miles distant from Hyderabad.

facts.text: Ramdhan resident of Peepalgaon in district of Parbhani; entire property there.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that Ramdhan was a resident of Peepalgaon in the district of Parbhani, and the entire property, movable as well as immovable, is at Peepalgaon itself.

facts.text: High Court concluded will prepared under suspicious circumstances, evidence unsatisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on a companysideration of the entire evidence adduced by the parties, came to the companyclusion that the will was prepared under highly suspicious circumstances, and that the evidence adduced by the appellant was number such as to satisfy it that the alleged will was a genuine one.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court right in rejecting the will.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we hold that the High Court was right in rejecting the evidence of the attesting witnesses and the scribe as well as of the appellant with regard to the exe- cution of the will by Ramdhan.

facts.text: Will executed at Hyderabad, where appellant resides.

anchor.surface_text: One is the fact that the will is said to have been executed at Hyderabad, which is a place where the appellant resides and carries on his profession as a medical practitioner and number at Peepalgaon, where Ramdhan resided.

facts.text: Ramdhan at Ghanegaon till afternoon on day prior to will execution; Ghanegaon 8 miles from Peepalgaon, nearest station 20 miles.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence adduced in the case shows that on the day prior to the one on which the will purports to have been executed, Ramdhan was at Ghanegaon till the afternoon. This place is 8 miles distant from Peepalgaon, and  the nearest railway station is 20 miles distant from Peepal- gaon.

facts.text: Will executed in appellant's house at about noon.

anchor.surface_text: The will is said-to have been executed at about numbern, and though it is number impossible, it is highly improbable that Ramdhan companyld have been present at the place of execution by that time. The third thing is that the will was executed in the house of the appellant.

prescribed in the case of a will by s. 63 of the Indian Succession Act. The onus of proving the will is on the propounder and in the absence of suspicious circumstances surrounding the execution of the will, proof of testamentary capacity and the signature of the testator as required by law is sufficient to discharge the onus.

concepts.unlisted_description: Special requirement of attestation for wills

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the mode of proof of a will, this Court has observed in H. Venkatachala lyengar v. B. N. Thimmajamma and Others 1  As in the case of proof of other documents so in the case of proof of wills it would be idle to expect proof with mathematical certainty. The test to be applied would be the usual test of the satisfaction of the prudent mind in such matters.

issues.text: whether a will alleged to have been executed by one Ramdhan on May 23, 1947 is genuine or is a fabrication

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for companysideration in this appeal by a certificate granted by the High Court of Bombay is whether a will alleged to have been executed by one Ramdhan on May 23, 1947 is genuine or is a fabrication.

issues.text: whether there was, in fact, a will, that is to say, whether Ramdhan did execute a will during his lifetime, and if so, whether the document upon which the appellant relies is a will executed by Ramdhan and duly attested by witnesses

anchor.surface_text: The questions which we have to companysider are whether there was, in fact, a will, that is to say, whether Ramdhan did execute a will during his lifetime, and if so, whether the document upon which the appellant relies is a will executed by Ramdhan and duly attested by witnesses.

issues.text: whether the appellants have succeeded in establishing that the will was duly executed and attested

anchor.surface_text: It is in the light of these settled principles that we have to companysider whether the appellants have succeeded in establishing that the will was duly executed and attested.

issues.text: whether the propounder has removed the suspicion arising from suspicious circumstances surrounding the execution of the will

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the mode of proof of a will, this Court has observed in H. Venkatachala lyengar v. B. N. Thimmajamma and Others 1  As in the case of proof of other documents so in the case of proof of wills it would be idle to expect proof with mathematical certainty. The test to be applied would be the usual test of the satisfaction of the prudent mind in such matters.

arguments.claim: Ramdhan could not have been at Hyderabad on May 23, 1947 to execute the will because he was at a village nearly 300 miles distant until the afternoon of the previous day.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the respondents have led evidence to show that Ramdhan could not have been at Hyderabad where the will is alleged to have been executed, on May 23, 1947, because till the afternoon of the previous day he was at a village nearly 300 miles distant from Hyderabad.

arguments.court_reasoning: Highly improbable for Ramdhan to travel from Ghanegaon (8 miles from Peepalgaon, railway 20 miles away) to Hyderabad by noon.

arguments.claim: Will is genuine and duly executed, proved by testimony of appellant, scribe Venkat Rajaram and attesting witnesses Raja Kaniahprasad, Rasheeduddin Ahmed and Wamanlal.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held in favour of the appellant that he was related to Ramdhan, as alleged by him, and that the will executed by Ramdhan was genuine. It also negatived Madanlals claim of having been adopted by Ramdhan.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court held will not genuine, dismissed suit; Supreme Court agrees.

arguments.claim: Will prepared under highly suspicious circumstances, appellant's evidence unsatisfactory, will not genuine.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on a consideration of the entire evidence adduced by the parties, came to the conclusion that the will was prepared under highly suspicious circumstances, and that the evidence adduced by the appellant was not such as to satisfy it that the alleged will was a genuine one.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court holds High Court was right in rejecting the will.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in approach by first considering circumstances then judging witness credibility with suspicious eye.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Dadachanji's grievance, however, is that the entire approach of the High Court to the evidence in this case was wrong, because it first took into consideration the various circumstances, and then judged the credibility of the witnesses in the light of those circumstances. In support of his contention, he has relied upon...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n which the appellant relies is a will executed by Ramdhan and duly attested by witnesses. The appellant can prove these facts only by adducing eviden

arguments.court_reasoning: Court entitled to consider surrounding circumstances and probabilities along with testimony to judge credibility.

arguments.claim: Court may consider surrounding circumstances and probabilities, not just demeanour, to judge witness credibility in will proof.

anchor.surface_text: The questions which we have to consider are whether there was, in fact, a will... In order to judge the credibility of the witnesses, the Court is not confined only to the way in which the witnesses have deposed or to the demeanour of witnesses, but it is open to it to look into the surrounding circumstances as well as the probabilities...

arguments.claim: Propounder must prove signature, testamentary capacity, understanding and free will; suspicious circumstances impose heavy onus to remove all suspicion.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the mode of proof of a will, this Court has observed in H. Venkatachala Iyengar v. B. N. Thimmajamma... The propounder would be called upon to show by satisfactory evidence that the will was signed by the testator, that the testator at the relevant time was in a sound and disposing state of mind...

arguments.claim: Madanlal was adopted son of Ramdhan in Chait Samvat 1999 according to prevailing custom in State of Udaipur.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the suit, one Madanlal was joined as a party to it on the basis of his claim to be the adopted son of Ramdhan. He also challenged the genuineness of the will. According to him, he was adopted by Ramdhan in the month of Chait, Samvat, 1999 according to the prevailing custom...

arguments.court_reasoning: Trial court negatived Madanlal's adoption claim.

arguments.claim: No execution of alleged will by Ramdhan, and appellant not related to Ramdhan.

anchor.surface_text: Sitabai denied the execution of the alleged will by Ramdhan, and also denied the relationship claimed by the appellant with Ramdhan.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ge of this fact ha,. set up a false will and laid claim to Ramdhans property. While admitting that the immovable property had been companyrectly set o

arguments.court_reasoning: Trial court accepted relationship but held will genuine (later rejected); Supreme Court does not address relationship.

arguments.claim: Execution at Hyderabad, appellant's residence and profession place, not Ramdhan's Peepalgaon, is suspicious.

anchor.surface_text: One is the fact that the will is said to have been executed at Hyderabad, which is a place where the appellant resides and carries on his profession as a medical practitioner and not at Peepalgaon, where Ramdhan resided.

arguments.claim: Ramdhan at Ghanegaon till afternoon previous day, 8 miles from Peepalgaon, railway station 20 miles away, highly improbable to reach Hyderabad by noon.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence adduced in the case shows that on the day prior to the one on which the will purports to have been executed, Ramdhan was at Ghanegaon till the afternoon. This place is 8 miles distant from Peepalgaon, and the nearest railway station is 20 miles distant from Peepalgaon.

arguments.claim: Will executed in appellant's house, suspicious.

anchor.surface_text: The will is said to have been executed at about noon... The third thing is that the will was executed in the house of the appellant.

arguments.claim: Propounder took prominent active part in execution of will conferring substantial benefits on him, suspicious circumstance requiring clear evidence to remove.

anchor.surface_text: where it appears that the propounder has taken a prominent part in the execution of the will which confers substantial benefits on him, that itself is generally treated as a suspicious circumstance

arguments.claim: Will unnatural: only Rs.40/month maintenance for widow, no residence, paltry bequests to daughters, entire property to distant relative not cared for by testator.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, there is the circumstance that the will is unnatural in the sense that though Ramdhan left property worth several lakhs, he made no provision for a residence for his wife but gave her only Rs. 40/- per month as her maintenance, and made only paltry bequests to his daughters.

arguments.claim: Strained relations alleged but Ramdhan lived with wife till death, no precautions for valuables or food despite poison suspicion, suspicious.

anchor.surface_text: All this is said to have been due to the fact that Ramdhans relations with his wife had become strained... Curiously enough, in spite of this, Ramdhan continued to live with Sitabai right till his death, and had made no arrangement...

holdings.text: The High Court was right in rejecting the evidence of the attesting witnesses and the scribe as well as of the appellant with regard to the execution of the will by Ramdhan.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we hold that the High Court was right in rejecting the evidence of the attesting witnesses and the scribe as well as of the appellant with regard to the exe- cution of the will by Ramdhan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspicious circumstances including improbability of testator's presence at execution site, execution at propounder's home, active role of propounder, unnatural dispositions, and poor quality document not removed by propounder's evidence.

holdings.text: The suspicion created by the circumstances has not been removed; there is not an iota of evidence in this regard, and we are not satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: There is not an iota of evidence in this regard, and we are not satisfied that the suspicion created by the circumstances referred to by us has been removed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Propounder failed to provide clear and satisfactory evidence to dispel suspicions arising from multiple attendant circumstances listed.

holdings.text: The appellants have not succeeded in establishing that the will was duly executed and attested.

anchor.surface_text: It is in the light of these settled principles that we have to consider whether the appellants have succeeded in establishing that the will was duly executed and attested.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of prudent mind test and onus under suspicious circumstances; evidence unsatisfactory after considering probabilities and circumstances.

holdings.text: To judge the credibility of witnesses in proof of will execution, the Court is not confined to demeanour or deposition but may look into surrounding circumstances and probabilities.

anchor.surface_text: In order to judge the credibility of the witnesses, the Court is not confined only to the way in which the witnesses have deposed or to the demeanour of witnesses, but it is open to it to look into the surrounding circumstances as well as the probabilities...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing prior cases; court must consider totality including circumstances to assess trustworthiness in will cases.

holdings.text: Where execution surrounded by suspicious circumstances, propounder must remove all legitimate suspicions by satisfactory evidence to satisfy the conscience of the court.

anchor.surface_text: The propounder would be called upon to show by satisfactory evidence that the will was signed by the testator... The presence of such suspicious circumstances naturally tends to make the initial onus very heavy...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following H. Venkatachala Iyengar and Shashi Kumar Banerjee; heavy onus where propounder benefits substantially and took active part.

holdings.text: The propounder took a prominent active part in the execution of the will conferring substantial benefits on him, which is a suspicious circumstance.

anchor.surface_text: where it appears that the propounder has taken a prominent part in the execution of the will which confers substantial benefits on him, that itself is generally treated as a suspicious circumstance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will executed at propounder's residence with his acquaintances as scribe and witnesses shortly after testator's improbable arrival.

precedents.citation: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand 1

anchor.surface_text: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand 1 , where it has been stated that in all cases in which a will is prepared under circumstances which arouse the suspicion of the Court that it does number express the mind of the testator, it is for the propounder of the will to remove that suspicion.

precedents.case_name: Sarat Kumari Bibi v Sakhi Chand
precedents.cited_proposition: In cases where a will is prepared under circumstances arousing suspicion that it does not express the testator's mind, the propounder must remove that suspicion.

anchor.surface_text: Kristo Gopal v. Baidya Nath 2  It is difficult to avoid the companyclusion that the learned Judges for some reason or other must have formed the idea that the will was number a genuine document, and that having formed such, an idea.

precedents.cited_proposition: Court should not approach evidence with pre-formed suspicion that will is not genuine; improbability must be clear and cogent.

precedents.case_name: Chotey Narain Singh v Mt Ratan Koer

precedents.cited_proposition: Mode of proof of wills; onus on propounder heavier if suspicious circumstances; must satisfy court's conscience.
